I move 120151 authorizing the director for the director's Designee to Scoot a real property lease with the central Pugent sound regional transit authority, sound transit for vacant land at 1000 northeast 45Th street, Seattle, Washington and ratifying prior acts and by referring this to the city council.

Yes.

Briefly for those just watching today for the first time colleagues Councilmember Lewis and I noted that we would like to add this bill to the introduction referral calendar and circulated Friday afternoon at 5:00 and we will vote on the actual bill, Monday, August 9th and plenty of time to review it and author the city to enter into a lease with sound transit so that the city can use the site for a tiny home village in district four to reduce homelessness.
Can I answer any questions?

Typically a lease can be entered into with the direction of the Fsa director if it involves a certain amount of square footage the Council had to give special direction to accept it and we are doing it here.
Performa thing but it has the potential to slow the village down if we don't move quickly to give the additional discretion to the director.

Very Performa thing and happy to support it and look forward to passing it next Monday.

Colleagues we will open it for items on the city council agenda and introduction and referral calendar and the Council's program.
I thank everybody for their patience and their cooperation to operate this remote public system.
The sister-in-law intent strong intent to have this but city Council has the right to eliminate these public hearings if it is no longer suitable for meeting to be conducted efficiently.
I will moderate the public comment period.
Public comment period for this meeting scheduled to be 20 minutes with each Speaker having up to 20 minute to speak as many of you heard our I.T.
Before we started streaming this meeting we have over 50 people signed up for public comment today.

So in an effort to hear as many if not all of those individuals that signed up for public comment I will extend the comment period but shorten the amount of time provided to each person from two minutes to a total of one minute.
This should allow us to hear from just about everyone that Preregistered for public comment this afternoon.
If there is no objection it will be extended to 60 minutes in total.
Hearing no objection it is extended to a total of 60 minutes.
I'll call on speakers in the order in which they Preregistered to provide comment on the Website.
Speakers must call in for the phone number used for this registration and using the Id and pass code Emailed to them upon confirmation.
Different than the general meeting line call in information.
Once that policy starts will you hear an automatic prompt as you have been Unmuted and that will be the Speaker's view to press Star 6 before speaking.
Please begin by stating your name and the item that you are addressing on today agenda.
The introduction referral calendar, or the Council's program.
Speakers, you will hear a Chime when ten seconds are left of your Alotted time.
Once you hear the Chime, please begin to wrap up your public comment.
If you do not end your comments at the end of the one minute have you been Alotted your microphone muted for the next Speaker.
Once you completed your public comment please connect from the line and if you plan to continue to form it you can do so with the listening objection.
The public comment period is now open.
And we will begin with a first Speaker on the list.
Again, once I call your name, you're going to hear a Prom if you have been Unmuted after you hear that prompt, press Star 6.
So we can hear you.
Kate Reuben is first.
Followed by Howard Gail.
Good afternoon.
I understand the new hope resolution introduced won't be voted on since August 9th but I am afraid of this to be diluted amendments and to support in full next week.
Black lives matter we must ensure that black community is not further displaced from the community.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Next up is Howard Gail and followed by Jacob sheer.
Good afternoon.
Howard Gail.
Over the last year we have seen repeated failures of every aspect of our police accountability system.

Last week the office of Inspector General released the findings on the police abuse of 2020 from a panel where more than half of the members were part of the failed system Outragely including five officers that have long history of abusing protestors and others.

Out of the 180 completed investigations representing thousands of complaints only three officers representing less than one percent of complaints have received other than a Reprimand with two officers receiving two days pension.
Before SPD killed John Williams, 22 people were killed by SPD.
During the decade the house is at 30.
How is this progress or accountability.
We need full discipline.
Go to Seattlestop.Org.
Thank you.
Next is Jacob sheer followed by Jared Brown.
Thank.

I am Jacob sheer and Organizer with real change and calling on behalf of them and full support of the city of Seattle to acknowledge and Attone for its act of complicity and to reinvest in affordable housing.
There is a direct connection between the current housing crisis and the rate of displacement policies of the city of Seattle enacted in the 60s.
Black families were uprooted from their community and displaced and under the guise of urban renewal.
All at the hands of the city of Seattle.
Homelessness impacts community of color because of races will policies.
They continue to Reverb Beret.
We need Council to go beyond rhetoric.
We need to address the housing crisis with acknowledging the history and the communities impacted by it.
Thank you.
Next up in Jared Brown followed by Jeremy Voss.
Hi.
This is Jared Brown in South Seattle.
Thank you city council.
I'm calling to discuss the NW exchange proposal.
This bill limits the SP D's ability to correspondent with organizations.
According to the provisions.
The SP D would he prevented from coordinating with other countries.
How can the SP D be effective fit can't partner and share intelligence with allies and our own country.
This ordinance does not add just the violence that SPD has to learn and address the excessive force.
It does waste the time of the city council when we can focus on solutions and excessive force in Seattle.
I ask that you oppose this ordinance and focus on the making a differences in Seattle lives.
Next up is Jeremy Voss.
Hi.
Can you hear me?
Yes.
My name is Jeremy Voss and I'm a President in district two.
I grew up in the Suehart community and speaking in favor of the bill.
These Trainings that SP D does are for indigenous people in the partner country as well as Seattle.

Not only do these exchanges Legitimatize the brutality of cops in both countries but they are also a place for cops to further sharpen and extend their tactics of brutality and surveillance and suppression of protestors.
The Council needs to transfer funds from SP D to marginalized community and not waste it on countries that are guilty of violating human rights.
So vote yes on 2142.
Thank you.

Greetings city.

And the supplement budget amendment to fund the affordable housing project proposed by missionary church and I will pass to Dr. Robert R. Jefffrey.

Hi.
My name is Danielle Holland.
I'm speaking in support of Councilmember Sawant's resolution as well and a couple of budget amendments to fully fund the affordable housing project proposed by missionary church.

Linked to the resolution will be an amendment and supplemental budget this month and we demand that the rest of the city council support Sawant's amendment to fund the land and refund the church for affordable housing to Seattle and hold accountability to the systemic racism red lining and Gentrification that has pushed out the black and Brown families for decades.
The city of Seattle has responsibility and now is the time.
Thank you.
Thank you, next is Jonah Silberstein follow by Zoe Bernstein.
Hi there.
I'm Jonas Silberstein and in support of 120142.
I'm a proud Jewish constituent and student at the University of Washington.
This legislation is common sense and supports the Council's mission to Defund SPD and reinvest in the community's most marginalized by its destructive and violent policies.

I believe that creating true safety and community requires SP D to cease all Trainings with countries that have been known to violate human rights and I would urge all city council members to support this resolution.
Thank you.
Next up is Zoe Bernstein followed by Reverend Jeffer.
Hello I'm El like and a Renner in district three asking you to vote no.
According Washington trafficking is serious.
Between 50700 children are forced into prostitution and that doesn't take in to County the victims.
The large numbers of those children are coming from Russia and China.
This ordinance would cripple the ability to eventually collaborate with counterparts in the countries that these victims are coming from.
Please, don't punish the very real victims of human trafficking in our own city because we want to take a stand against human rights abroad.
It is because Seattle has its identity I ask you to vote against this ordinance.
Thank you.
Next is Reverend Robert Jeffries.
My name is Robert Jeffree senior pastor of the missionary church and I am in support of Councilwoman Sawant's proposal.
New hope is being described as institution that has allowed voice and its overpowering of its voices.
This is the same thing that people use when you go to apply for a job when they say you are over--that you are Overqualified.
New hope church has been in this city for the last 70 years.

We have had injustices perpetrated against us and two unexplained fires and land taken from us which was adjacent to our church and all kinds of discriminatory practices levied against us and we are Overqualified to get money to build--that to me is unacceptable.
Thank you.
Thank you, Reverend.
Next up is Jessica Scalzo.
Hi, my name is Jessica Scalzo.
I am a Renter in district three and part of the tax Amazon movement.
I am very excited about Councilmember Sawant resolution that she is bringing forward to demand that city recognize race practices and fund new hope to the tune of $10 million and no less.
It is important that we start to undo the damage done by red lining.
With the Amazon tax movement we only got 18 million as a fund to build aid Fordable homes in the central district for black families pushed out.
We need to increase that as well as make sure that all 90 affordable hopes in this new hope project are completed.
So I am encouraging all Councilmembers to vote in favor of this and let's start working today.
Thank you.
Next is Alonna Le brick.
I am in support of Councilwoman Sawant resolution.

I am a vote are standing with my neighbors outside of new hope church and ask the Council to fully fund the affordable housing project proposed by new hope church and the Council to vote on this by August 9th.
This resolution is wonderful first step in writing historical wrongs against the black community in Seattle.
I urge city Council to vote yes on the new hope resolution and show that black lives matter to the city of Seattle.
Thank you so much.
Thank you for calling in.
Next up is Robin Thompson.
I have Dustin Willsor that is showing up as not present.

Vote without any further delay than August 9th to approve Councilmember Sawant's resolution to fully fund the affordable housing project pro posed by new hope church.
I usually the Council to vote in full with no last minute changes to the resolution.
Seattle city council must not remain complicit to the racist removal of black and Brown families.
Vote yes.
I urge couple to make a formal commitment to fund this and others to right the wrongs and move black people that have been displaced.
The council must not divide the black community by policing the community and church by saying it has too loud of a voice.
Rents have risen by 20% this year.
Only 15% of the black community remains in the central district.
Stop toned policing and start taking responsibility and writing the wrongs by voting yes and increasing Amazon and putting it towards the resolution and other housing.

We think black lives matter and we put our actions and money behind our words.

John.

The city Council has taken concrete steps to undue the legacy of racism and that should be commended but why are talking about a harm that is Unmended and it is never too late to make a wrong a right.
The city should apologize and give the land back and fund the new hope Baptist church project.

The Seattle office of emergency management maintains what is call an all hazard mitigation plan.

Updated every five years and includes evolving information on community led adjustments to reflect emerging values and cooperation with other major citywide plans and additional Department engagement.

The Office of emergency management presented their draft, all hazards update to the public safety and human services Committee in mid-June and then again last week where we unanimously passed out resolution 32011.
I put forward an amendment supported unanimously and that amendment asked the office of emergency management to do two things.
The first is to develop a strategy to brief communities in the city of Seattle under the Sea-Tac International airport in King County International Airport flight path.
To update them on information on existing city, County and port of Seattle planning efforts that may relate to plane crash hazard mitigation.
Following such briefings, report back to the council about whether or not there is any gaps within the all hazards mitigation plan.

The second part of the amendment" that the office of emergency management coordinate a citywide effort to identify approaches and projects which can mitigate the impacts of excessive heat on July NER and populations in Seattle.

The Office of emergency management is requested to engage multiple city departments and private sector partners and other subject matter experts including public health Seattle King County and the office of Sustainability and the environment.

The first part of this amendment was developed with the Georgetown neighborhood after they reached out to me with concerns regarding King County International interim and the possibility of a plane crash related emergency.
The second part of the amendment recognizes that all hazard mitigation plan addresses excessive heat but we need to do more as heat waves are more common in Northwest.

In June we had a hearing on this bill with central staff President to answer questions to the committee's satisfaction.
There were some slight changes that were made in consultation over the course of the month of July leading up to last month's committee meeting where CBO made a few technical changes to this bill.
The committee then reported it out with no votes in opposition and I believe seven, eight or seven votes in favor.

You know, just to speak to this briefly, this bill before us will create a dedicated city fund to accept private contributions per approval from the Seattle city council the same way we approve all external grants and contribution of money to the municipal coffers in order to engage in homelessness shelter and services projects, there are a number of Stakeholders out there interested in figuring out ways to expedite efforts that the Council has in many cases already funded but ways that those--the impact to be stretched even further by taking advantage of offers from potential partners.

Private Philanthropy is never going to replace conservative government action to solve the big problems that face our society including the state of emergency on homelessness but when folk step forward to serve it could make a discernible difference and we should as a city carve out some space to engage in those partnerships when possible.
With that, I urge passage of this bill and look forward to move it out.
Thank you.
